newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine blue-chips end lower in muted trade.
newsitem.headline: Argentine blue-chips end lower in muted trade.

text.p: Argentine stocks closed lower Thursday in a cautious, low-volume market largely deserted by institutional investors, traders said.
"The market was emptier. The Brazil stock exchange fall meant institutional investors stayed away," one trader said.
The blue-chip MerVal index .MERV ended 1.33 percent lower at 815.35, after having been 0.45 percent up midsession.
"The market had a go at rising at the beginning of the session, but without much confidence, especially because there was little volume," said Gabriel Ruiz of Tavelli y Compania.
He said Brazilian fears continued to prey on the market.
"Without doubt everyone is totally absorbed by the volatility in the Brazilian market," said Ruiz.
He said that the Buenos Aires market changed direction and headed south when Sao Paulo's Bovespa index began to fall and rumors reemerged of a possible Brazilian devaluation.
The MerVal ended up 2.28 percent at 826.37 Wednesday. But it was spooked by Brazilian devaluation rumors Tuesday and lost five percent in the first two days of the week.
"The market is reorganizing itself with selective profit-taking. The base is solid and the Merval is showing strong support at 800 points," an analyst said.
Turnover was $30.2 million, with 21 stocks closing higher, 36 down, and 17 unchanged.
"The outlook's good, especially for construction and oil after the good placement of YPF shares," a broker said.
Ten percent of shares in oil firm YPF, which previously belonged to the firm's employees, were sold at $29.25 each Wednesday. YPF closed up 0.35 pesos at 30.40 pesos.
Sao Paulo's Bovespa lost 7.22 percent Thursday.
